awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Electoral Systems as Incentive Structures for Interparty and Intraparty Politics
awd_abstract_narration:
Why does the nature of representation vary across countries, states, and localities? Despite the fact that most politicians work hard to prove they deserve re-election, citizens often express frustration with the behavior of their elected officials.  This project develops a new data set based on at least 2750 elections for national legislatures in nearly 150 countries for a 75 year period. The data will be used to test to what extent the type of representation citizens receive is a function of the electoral rules used to choose their representatives. Specifically, the project examines whether electoral rules explain variation in interparty politics — the number of parties and the variety of the policies they promise — and intraparty politics — the balance representatives strike between offering their constituents programmatic policy or particularistic rewards and constituency service.

This project tests whether electoral rules explain variation in interparty politics — the effective number of parties, parties’ locations in the policy space, congruence between citizens’ preferences and policy — and intraparty politics — the content of campaigns, the amount of constituency service provided, the design of legislative institutions, levels of party discipline, and the balance struck between programmatic policy and pork barrel politics. The effort is unique in two ways. First, the project compiles a dataset with the details of the systems used to conduct more than 2,750 elections for national legislatures in nearly 150 countries for a 75-year-period.  Second, it uses simulations to transparently generate interval-level indicators of the extent to which , on the interparty dimension, electoral systems encourage voters to express their heterogeneous preferences for a wide array of offerings and, on the intraparty front, allow voters to fill legislatures with noteworthy individuals as opposed to party automatons.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our research focuses on how electoral systems affect the behavior of politicians and citizens. We have known for a long while that electoral systems incentivize voters and their representatives to act in differentiated but predictable ways. For example, the single member district plurality electoral system employed to elect congressional representatives in the US tends to motivate politicians to appeal to middle-of-the-road voters, deliver constituency services, and develop personalistic “brands” that are somewhat independent of their political party. This same rule motivates voters to avoid voting for a preferred candidate that has no chance of winning the election (this is the logic of “wasted votes”).   

The problem that we address is that we lack good measures of electoral incentives. Other than impressionistic assessments about how this or that rule “tends to motivate” actors, we cannot parse out the strength of these effects without valid and reliable measures. Our research uses computer simulations to develop two summary measures of the incentives encoded in every conceivable electoral system, which includes systems that do not yet exist, but could arguably be employed in a polity. We then use these two summary measures to score actual electoral systems used in all elections since 1950 in 150+ countries around the world. Each of these electoral systems now has one score that summarizes how voters and politicians would think to engage in competition with other political parties, and a second score that synthesizes how these actors would relate to other actors within the same political party. In short, we manage to encode incentives along both an inter-party and an intra-party dimension.

With adequately-scored electoral systems in hand, we test more than a dozen observable implications of existing theory for interparty and intraparty politics. The main scholarly outcome of our work is a book, Electoral System Incentives for Interparty and Intraparty Politics (Oxford University Press, forthcoming), that summarizes the computer simulation work, the scoring algorithm that we employ, and the evidence that we have collected in support of theories about political behavior under different electoral incentives. Additionally, an accompanying website (https://i3dataset.com/) will make available to the wider public the dataset of electoral systems that we compiled (the website will go live upon publication of the book). More importantly, the website showcases a dashboard in which any individual can toggle different electoral rules within an electoral system to display the kind of incentives that such a “reformed” electoral system would be expected to create (image included). This tool allows citizens and practitioners the chance to understand the consequences of different electoral rules before advocating for their implementation.
